Award.AwardTitle: Extracting Seismic Core Phases with Array Interferometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Methods that make use of seismic interferometry and ambient noise energy have proven to be extremely useful in imaging shallow Earth structure. Since application of such ambient noise techniques is not limited to where earthquakes occur, if the techniques could be applied to the deep Earth then we would drastically increase our ability to sample the deep Earth. While most studies using ambient seismic noise have failed to retrieve deep body-wave phases, new work of ours suggests that cross correlating body-wave coda emitted by large earthquakes combined with appropriate stacking of array data allows extraction of seismic phases that reflect off the Earth's core and that travel through the Earth's inner core. Currently, however, we do not fully understand why the technique works or what the limitations are. We will develop this ambient-noise/earthquake-coda core-imaging technique more fully, including understanding the basis for the method, improving the process, and applying it to interesting datasets. Promising areas of application include imaging inner core anisotropy, core mantle boundary topography, and deep mantle structure.

The fundamental purpose of this work is to develop a new method of imaging the deep Earth that relies on low-amplitude but coherent waves that are part of Earth's ambient noise field. Successful application of the imaging method will provide detailed constraints on how the Earth's core has evolved, on the composition of the deep Earth, and on Earth processes in general. Our line of research will also enable us to assess the full potential of this technique to advance current imaging capabilities in the Earth sciences, but also medical imaging, and oil and gas exploration. Finally, since a crucial aspect of the method is its reliance on waves that take unusual paths, including being scattered and multiply reflected by Earth structure, understanding the method will provide new insight into the heterogeneity of Earth structure and other aspects of the Earth that cause unusual wave propagation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The center of the Earth is nearly 4000 miles from the Earth’s surface, and this large distance makes it challenging to measure properties of the deep Earth. For example, while the existence of the Earth’s solid inner core has been known for decades, a wide range of questions still exists about the dynamics of this region of the Earth and implications for Earth history. The primary way in which the core’s structure has been determined is through measuring the large-amplitude seismic waves that travel through the Earth and return back to the Earth’s surface at seismic stations. However, since earthquakes only occur in specific places around the world, the paths that have been constrained have been limited. To address this issue, we have developed a new method of probing the deep Earth using the low-amplitude but coherent waves that reverberate inside the Earth many hours after an earthquake occurs. This ‘body-wave interferometry’ method shares many features with other forms of interferometry that have been applied to imaging shallow Earth structure, and allows measurements to be made between any two seismic stations on Earth, rather than needing to rely on the distribution of earthquakes. Unexpectedly, however, the method works well for certain types of seismic arrivals but not others, and we tested why this is. Test results showed that certain types of reverberations dominate when interferometry is used. Perhaps more importantly, we also discovered that some measurements are strongly influenced by differential arrivals rather than direct arrivals and that some measurements are biased by the interferometry. To successfully make use of body-wave interferometry data, both of these issues must be recognized and either accounted for or avoided. Accounting for these issues, we performed body-wave seismic interferometry across the United States, using the densely-spaced USArray seismic array. These measurements showed significant anomalies in the deep Earth that may be due to the western part of the inner core having subtly different properties from the eastern part of the inner core. Furthermore, we have imaged these east/west changes in significantly different locations than previously imaged, suggesting that the orientation of the boundaries may change with depth in the inner core. Potentially, this could mean that inner core solidification has not been spatially uniform and that locations of higher solidification rates have rotated relative to the rest of the Earth over the timespan of millions of years. This in turn has important implications for the formation the inner core and thus the thermal history of the planet. Over the course of this work, graduate students and postdoctoral scientists were trained, and the work was used in outreach materials for engaging the general public with science.
